statements.name: PROC SQOOP
statements.description: Allows access to Apache Sqoop using options to allow data transfer between a database and HDFS.

arguments.name: COMMAND=
arguments.description: specifies the Apache Sqoop command. Here is how you must specify the command:

arguments.name: DBPWD=
arguments.description: specifies the database password that is associated with the DBUSER option. Because this option is mutually exclusive with the PASSWORDFILE= option, you must specify only one or the other.

arguments.name: DBUSER=
arguments.description: specifies the database user name to use for import or export.

arguments.name: HADOOPPWD=
arguments.description: specifies the Hadoop password that is associated with the HADOOPUSER= option.

arguments.name: HADOOPUSER=
arguments.description: specifies the Hadoop user name to use for import or export.

arguments.name: OOZIEURL=
arguments.description: specifies the URL to the Oozie server.

arguments.name: DELETEWF
arguments.description: specifies that, if an Oozie workflow file exists as specified by the location in WFHDFSPATH, it should be deleted. The SQOOP procedure then creates a new workflow file at that location.

arguments.name: HIVE_SERVER=
arguments.description: specifies the Hive server name that runs the Hive service and the port number to use to connect to the specified Hive service.

arguments.name: JOBTRACKER=
arguments.description: specifies the URL to the JobTracker or ResourceManager services.

arguments.name: NAMENODE=
arguments.description: specifies the URL to the NameNode services.

arguments.name: PASSWORDFILE=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the file that is located in HDFS that contains the database password for import or export. This separate password file must exist before you can run this procedure, and care should be taken to keep this file secure.

arguments.name: WFHDFSPATH=
arguments.description: specifies the path and filename for where to upload the Oozie workflow, as shown below.
